ftp-server.name: ftp-server
ftp-server.role: Corporate file server running vulnerable FTP service with misconfigured permissions

files.name: vsftpd.conf
files.content:
# vsftpd configuration - Anonymous FTP
listen=YES
anonymous_enable=YES
anon_upload_enable=NO
anon_mkdir_write_enable=NO
anon_root=/ftp
no_anon_password=YES
write_enable=YES
local_enable=YES
chroot_local_user=YES
allow_writeable_chroot=YES
secure_chroot_dir=/var/run/vsftpd/empty
pam_service_name=vsftpd
pasv_enable=YES
pasv_min_port=21100
pasv_max_port=21110
userlist_enable=NO

files.name: start.sh
files.content:
#!/bin/bash
mkdir -p /ftp/public /ftp/data /ftp/private
echo "CTF{network_ftp_anon_rs9xqdsk2t}" > /ftp/data/flag.txt
chmod 644 /ftp/data/flag.txt
echo "Welcome to the CTF FTP Server!" > /ftp/public/welcome.txt
echo "Important files may be in subdirectories" > /ftp/public/readme.txt
service vsftpd start
tail -f /dev/null

files.name: README.txt
files.content:
FTP Challenge (Easy)

Objective:
Connect to the FTP server and find the flag.

Hints:
1. Anonymous access is enabled
2. Explore all directories
3. Check subdirectories

Tools:
- ftp
- nmap
- wget/curl

Flag Format: CTF{...}

network.misconfiguration: Anonymous FTP access enabled with sensitive files
network.exploitPath: Connect via anonymous FTP and navigate to /data directory
network.setup:
apt-get update && apt-get install -y vsftpd
cp /challenge/vsftpd.conf /etc/vsftpd.conf
mkdir -p /var/run/vsftpd/empty
chmod +x /challenge/start.sh
/challenge/start.sh
